BLUE JAY
ELECTS FIVE
Five men were elected to
the art and editoral boards
of the Black and Blue Jay
at a board of control meeting held shortly before the
beginning of the Christmas
recess. M. Hamburger '28,
M. Mauchly '29 and R. Nyburg '29 are the three new
members of the editoral staff.
W. Banks and J. Hurwitz
'29 have been made members
of the art staff.

Basketball holds 11w major part
of attention in the opening of the
192G sport calendar. U. of M.
covered herself with a bit of glory
when she walked off with a victory
over -Navy just as the 1925 season
went out. University of Virginia
is planning on coming up to the
Marylanders home grounds and
avenging a defeat which the Ravens administered to a southern
team of Captains last year. The
Virginians and U. of M. will meet
twice this year, once at College
'Park and once at Charlottesville.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 8, 1926.

GRATITUDE
The letter we are reproducing in an adjoining column is
indicative of the true spirit of gratitude, of manliness.in facing
difficult problems, of splendid effort in times of stress by that
once villified nation—Germany.
Courage is its essence, courage and independence of a finer
sort. The mere fact that the German students are considering
the money sent them in their hour of need from the ample
resources of America, as a loan shows a splendid spirit on their
part, a spirit that many governments could well copy. That
.these impoverished students worked out their own salvation by
breaking with tradition and custom implies strength and selfreliance not to be expected from a less virile nation.
That the response of American students to German need
has obliterated any rancor left , over from the bitter years of
war, as far as the students are concerned, is evident from the
tone of the letter. We believe that Germany has a new spirit, a
new independence, and we are publishing the communication
as one proof of our belief. It is a lesson in courage, in gentlemanliness.

A NEW YEAR'S RESOLUTION
-Louder and funnier," shouts the smart guy when a word of
discipline chanCei his way. The coming point is not new, but on
the contrary, rather threadbare, and has always had the fate of
being shouted down.
Once more let us ask: When are the students of the University going to stop destroying what last vestige of grass we have
left on our once artistic campus? Every day finds the already
wide paths wider still, and other bare spots appearing here and
there. Once upon a time, several years ago a progressive student
council contrived to have tiny signs with the one word "PLEASE"
placed in the path of those who would wander wantonly on the
green. These efforts brought little result and the last of the
signs passed from existence last year. Once again the students
were left unmolested to cut byways for themselves across the
campus.
Now a new menace is with us. Mark ye the edges of the
driveway about the quadrangle and past the Barn. The hard
surface of the drive is tinged almost everywhere by a strip of
brown mud. Hostile tires of careless drivers have torn away the
last remnants of bordering green.
The humble plea, "PLEASE," has been successfully drowned
out by "louder and funnier." Lt us hope this stronger plea may
chance to survive.
Campus pedestrians and motorists, make this your New
Year's resolution!

Basketball is doomed to wait
at Johns Hopkins due to the lack
of a suitable gymnasium for practices and games. If a good enough
court is obtained there may be a
quintet next season.
*
*
*
*
The first big thing to which
Homewood has to look is the
Johns Hopkins Fifth Regiment
Meet to be held in the latter part
of February. It. is hoped that
1Houben and possibly some of the
,other foreign stars will attend
ithese games. Hopkins will be repfresented in one or two other in:door meets but the team will center its attention on outdoor track
for which a nice schedule has been
drawn up. The outdoor season
will. open with Randolph-Macon
on April 10.
One week before the opening of
,the cinder path at Homewood, lacrosse will inaugurate spring athletics with a game with St. Johns.
It will be the first Hopkins-St.
Johns meeting in the Indian sport.
Under the Captaincy of'Levy and
the supervision of CoaCh Schmeisser,,the team will go thru a crack:
er-jack schedule that will have for
its high spots, Oxford-Cambridge,
Onandago, Army and Maryland.
Army will venture southward for
the first time in the history of the
Academy when she comes to play
on Homewood field.
Lacrosse is slowly but surely
becoming a scientific game. The
game has come down from the old
Indian conflict in which whole
'families engaged and in which at
least a few deaths were expected
:to be the toll from the crowd who
,played on each side, to a contest
• are ex,in which serious injuries
of play
style
tremely rare! The
inwhich
in
has evolved from one
thing
dividual play was the big
to a form in which team work is
essential. The old player in the
game of the aborigines broke away
from the crowd,scooped up the ball
and ran, without thinking of passing, to the goal line of his opponents. He carried the ball in a
little "crosse," a scant twelve inches in circumference and hence had
very little opportunity for passing.
A successful pass demanded great
skill.

Vernon 2355
CHEMISTS MARK YULETIDE BLUE JAY ORCHESTRA TO
THE FLAG, BANNER AND PENNANT SHOP
WITH BURLESQUE
PLAY ON BROADWAY
SUCCESSORS TO SISCO BROS.
(Cont. from p. 1, col. 3)
Hold A Laugh Fest Instead Of The
Usual Journal Meeting
certs, they have played each Sat-

Every Monday afternoon the
Chemistry Department professors
and graduate students hold a journal meeting, but on Monday,. December 21, they held a Christmas
party instead. Not a quarter of
those who attended the meeting
in -Room 221 of the Chemistry
Building were aware of the nature of the proceedings until Dr.
Rice opened the conference with
a humorous speechNext followed novel pictures of
the faculty—pictures about which
none of those who had seen them
could talk without choking --with
laughter and which they did not
seem to care to discuss. - Evidently the professors had been playing
pranks whose nature they did not
wish to disclose to the undergraduates.
Dr. Patrick demonstrated a new
machine whereby he could tell
whether a man's _utterances were
serious or otherwise. He tried
the machine on several members
of the faculty with varying success.
Professor Dillingham's recital
of a poem was followed by the
appearance of S. Claus (Dr. Copenhaver) riding upon an inverted jar with several two-legged
reindeer to drag him. Refreshments were served to the chemists
before the final adjournment of
the meeting.

Marksmen Defeat
West Virginians
Continuing its unbroken series
of victories, the Rifle Team outshot the marksmen of -the University of West Virginia and triumphed by a total of 3770 points
to 3584. The ten highest of,fifteen
scores were counted in the match.
This week the Hopkins riflemen
are pitted against those of the
University of Syracuse.

Dr. Weatherford
To Give Talk
"Finding One's Place in the
World" will be the subject of a
talk by Dr. -W. D. Weatherford,
President of the Southern Y. M.
C. A. College, Nashville, Tennessee, nejtt Sunday afternoon,- January 10, at 5 P. M.
The meeting, to which all students are invited, will be held at
the Friends' Meeting House, 3107
N Charles Street. Dr. Weatherford is known as one of the liveliest men engaged in the Y M C
A. student work.
Tea will be served to those who
care to avail themselves of this
opportunity to hear the speaker.

A fulcrum for every
modern Archimedes

The clothing store
that knows the difference
between real and imitation College style

IVE me a fulcrum—and I will move the earth"
said Archimedes. Too bad that he lived
twenty-two hundred years too soon.
For .tou modern followers of Archimedes, you
men who apply his well known principles in the
study of mechanical engineering, the fulcrum is
ready. If a part in helping the earth to move
appeals to you, look for your fulcrum in the
communication art.
A world of possibilities opens up here for the
man whose bent is mechanical. Distances shrink
because mechanical engineers have found how to
draw well-nigh every bit of air out of a repeater
tube. A million telephones are made—and the
millionth is like the first because mechanical ingenuity has shown the way. Quantity production
in a great telephone plant calls for constant improvement in mechanical technique.
Every day is a day of new facts, new things,
new achievements by mechanical and electrical
engineers. Nothing stands still. Here the world
does move.

"G

HEYWARD E. BOYCE, President

have a typewriter (or borrow one).
You'll get along better -this term
if you buy your typewriter now

Basketball holds 11w major part
of attention in the opening of the
192G sport calendar. U. of M.
covered herself with a bit of glory
when she walked off with a victory
over -Navy just as the 1925 season
went out. University of Virginia
is planning on coming up to the
Marylanders home grounds and
avenging a defeat which the Ravens administered to a southern
team of Captains last year. The
Virginians and U. of M. will meet
twice this year, once at College
'Park and once at Charlottesville.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 8, 1926.

GRATITUDE
The letter we are reproducing in an adjoining column is
indicative of the true spirit of gratitude, of manliness.in facing
difficult problems, of splendid effort in times of stress by that
once villified nation—Germany.
Courage is its essence, courage and independence of a finer
sort. The mere fact that the German students are considering
the money sent them in their hour of need from the ample
resources of America, as a loan shows a splendid spirit on their
part, a spirit that many governments could well copy. That
.these impoverished students worked out their own salvation by
breaking with tradition and custom implies strength and selfreliance not to be expected from a less virile nation.
That the response of American students to German need
has obliterated any rancor left , over from the bitter years of
war, as far as the students are concerned, is evident from the
tone of the letter. We believe that Germany has a new spirit, a
new independence, and we are publishing the communication
as one proof of our belief. It is a lesson in courage, in gentlemanliness.

A NEW YEAR'S RESOLUTION
-Louder and funnier," shouts the smart guy when a word of
discipline chanCei his way. The coming point is not new, but on
the contrary, rather threadbare, and has always had the fate of
being shouted down.
Once more let us ask: When are the students of the University going to stop destroying what last vestige of grass we have
left on our once artistic campus? Every day finds the already
wide paths wider still, and other bare spots appearing here and
there. Once upon a time, several years ago a progressive student
council contrived to have tiny signs with the one word "PLEASE"
placed in the path of those who would wander wantonly on the
green. These efforts brought little result and the last of the
signs passed from existence last year. Once again the students
were left unmolested to cut byways for themselves across the
campus.
Now a new menace is with us. Mark ye the edges of the
driveway about the quadrangle and past the Barn. The hard
surface of the drive is tinged almost everywhere by a strip of
brown mud. Hostile tires of careless drivers have torn away the
last remnants of bordering green.
The humble plea, "PLEASE," has been successfully drowned
out by "louder and funnier." Lt us hope this stronger plea may
chance to survive.
Campus pedestrians and motorists, make this your New
Year's resolution!

Basketball is doomed to wait
at Johns Hopkins due to the lack
of a suitable gymnasium for practices and games. If a good enough
court is obtained there may be a
quintet next season.
*
*
*
*
The first big thing to which
Homewood has to look is the
Johns Hopkins Fifth Regiment
Meet to be held in the latter part
of February. It. is hoped that
1Houben and possibly some of the
,other foreign stars will attend
ithese games. Hopkins will be repfresented in one or two other in:door meets but the team will center its attention on outdoor track
for which a nice schedule has been
drawn up. The outdoor season
will. open with Randolph-Macon
on April 10.
One week before the opening of
,the cinder path at Homewood, lacrosse will inaugurate spring athletics with a game with St. Johns.
It will be the first Hopkins-St.
Johns meeting in the Indian sport.
Under the Captaincy of'Levy and
the supervision of CoaCh Schmeisser,,the team will go thru a crack:
er-jack schedule that will have for
its high spots, Oxford-Cambridge,
Onandago, Army and Maryland.
Army will venture southward for
the first time in the history of the
Academy when she comes to play
on Homewood field.
Lacrosse is slowly but surely
becoming a scientific game. The
game has come down from the old
Indian conflict in which whole
'families engaged and in which at
least a few deaths were expected
:to be the toll from the crowd who
,played on each side, to a contest
• are ex,in which serious injuries
of play
style
tremely rare! The
inwhich
in
has evolved from one
thing
dividual play was the big
to a form in which team work is
essential. The old player in the
game of the aborigines broke away
from the crowd,scooped up the ball
and ran, without thinking of passing, to the goal line of his opponents. He carried the ball in a
little "crosse," a scant twelve inches in circumference and hence had
very little opportunity for passing.
A successful pass demanded great
skill.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, JANUARY 8, 1926.
Vernon 2355
CHEMISTS MARK YULETIDE BLUE JAY ORCHESTRA TO
THE FLAG, BANNER AND PENNANT SHOP
WITH BURLESQUE
PLAY ON BROADWAY
SUCCESSORS TO SISCO BROS.
(Cont. from p. 1, col. 3)
Hold A Laugh Fest Instead Of The
Usual Journal Meeting
certs, they have played each Sat-

Every Monday afternoon the
Chemistry Department professors
and graduate students hold a journal meeting, but on Monday,. December 21, they held a Christmas
party instead. Not a quarter of
those who attended the meeting
in -Room 221 of the Chemistry
Building were aware of the nature of the proceedings until Dr.
Rice opened the conference with
a humorous speechNext followed novel pictures of
the faculty—pictures about which
none of those who had seen them
could talk without choking --with
laughter and which they did not
seem to care to discuss. - Evidently the professors had been playing
pranks whose nature they did not
wish to disclose to the undergraduates.
Dr. Patrick demonstrated a new
machine whereby he could tell
whether a man's _utterances were
serious or otherwise. He tried
the machine on several members
of the faculty with varying success.
Professor Dillingham's recital
of a poem was followed by the
appearance of S. Claus (Dr. Copenhaver) riding upon an inverted jar with several two-legged
reindeer to drag him. Refreshments were served to the chemists
before the final adjournment of
the meeting.

Marksmen Defeat
West Virginians
Continuing its unbroken series
of victories, the Rifle Team outshot the marksmen of -the University of West Virginia and triumphed by a total of 3770 points
to 3584. The ten highest of,fifteen
scores were counted in the match.
This week the Hopkins riflemen
are pitted against those of the
University of Syracuse.

Dr. Weatherford
To Give Talk
"Finding One's Place in the
World" will be the subject of a
talk by Dr. -W. D. Weatherford,
President of the Southern Y. M.
C. A. College, Nashville, Tennessee, nejtt Sunday afternoon,- January 10, at 5 P. M.
The meeting, to which all students are invited, will be held at
the Friends' Meeting House, 3107
N Charles Street. Dr. Weatherford is known as one of the liveliest men engaged in the Y M C
A. student work.
Tea will be served to those who
care to avail themselves of this
opportunity to hear the speaker.

IVE me a fulcrum—and I will move the earth"
said Archimedes. Too bad that he lived
twenty-two hundred years too soon.
For .tou modern followers of Archimedes, you
men who apply his well known principles in the
study of mechanical engineering, the fulcrum is
ready. If a part in helping the earth to move
appeals to you, look for your fulcrum in the
communication art.
A world of possibilities opens up here for the
man whose bent is mechanical. Distances shrink
because mechanical engineers have found how to
draw well-nigh every bit of air out of a repeater
tube. A million telephones are made—and the
millionth is like the first because mechanical ingenuity has shown the way. Quantity production
in a great telephone plant calls for constant improvement in mechanical technique.
Every day is a day of new facts, new things,
new achievements by mechanical and electrical
engineers. Nothing stands still. Here the world
does move.
